stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on modeling and programming for a large, multi-room ice castle level. Key activities included refactoring the game's mirror system, implementing a custom per-level memory allocator to fix a collision crash, and attempting to diagnose a persistent lighting bug that occurs on emulators.

development_findings.summary: A key technical discovery, made with contributor Sauraen, was that the RSP (Reality Signal Processor) is the main performance bottleneck, not the RDP. This insight led to performance gains when switching to the FBDX3 microcode.
development_findings.quote: We Found out that the bottleneck is actually the rsp and not the rdp... that's the entire reason my course one was like stuck at 46 fps because the rsp was the bottleneck.

development_findings.summary: Kaze successfully refactored the game's mirror system from a clunky, hardcoded implementation to a flexible, data-driven one, making it significantly easier to create new mirror surfaces.
development_findings.quote: Dude, this is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

development_findings.summary: To solve a crash caused by exceeding the collision triangle limit in a large level, Kaze implemented a custom memory allocator that assigns memory on a per-level basis.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, I made my own memory allocator. What about it?

development_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges that optimizing the FBDX3 microcode is extremely difficult and requires deep, specialized knowledge of the N64's RSP, which he plans to learn in the future.
development_findings.quote: The problem with it is that it's so difficult that just being creative with code is not good enough. You need to actually be really, really good at programming to be able to contribute anything to X3.

development_findings.summary: A persistent bug causes the game's lighting to break when a second light source appears, specifically on emulators. The ambient light disappears, and Kaze has not yet identified the cause.
Kaze is confident that despite current low framerates during development, the final level will achieve 60 FPS on console once rooms and culling are properly implemented.
development_findings.quote: The game is rendering the entire castle at the same time right now... The entire castle is either gonna run 60 fps in the end i'm pretty sure.

development_findings.summary: The game will not be playable on the popular SM64 PC Port because it uses custom graphics combiners that the port does not support.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is motivated to work and stream more frequently due to the financial needs of being a new father, though he is unsure how he will manage the time.
context_findings.quote: I have a child now and I need more money. So hopefully there will be more streams, but I don't know how I'm going to manage the time wise since I do have a full-time job on top of being all of this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that for most general applications, the specific high-level programming language used is irrelevant, and that skilled programmers should be language-agnostic.
context_findings.quote: If you care at all, like even just a little bit about which programming language you use, that is a very strong indicator that you're a terrible programmer.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is acutely aware of the legal risks from Nintendo and has no plans for a physical release, instead opting for a patch-based distribution model.
context_findings.quote: I can't physically release this game, Christian. Because if I do, I will get giga sued by Nintendo.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal story about nearly being phished by a fake advertiser, highlighting his security-consciousness by refusing to download an executable file.
In a brief, personal exchange with the chat, Kaze mentions he has stopped taking his bipolar medication.
Kaze plans a multi-stage release: v1.0 and v1.1 will support emulators, but subsequent versions will drop emulator support to fully optimize the game for original N64 hardware.
context_findings.quote: I am going to release an emulator version of the finished game first... And then I will ditch emulator support entirely.

biobak.summary: Kaze implies that Biobak, the graphics artist, has very high standards for geometric precision and visual quality, and he adjusts his modeling work to meet these expectations.
biobak.quote: Why didn't you make it perfect squares? I don't know. Fix it now while you can. Before the wrath of Biobak murders me.

biobak.summary: Kaze feels a responsibility to bring the level geometry to a certain standard of quality before handing it off to Biobak for texture and art work.
biobak.quote: Really, it's just kind of getting these rooms to look a little nicer. So it's not insulting to Biobak when I pass this over.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present in the stream chat and had lighthearted personal interactions with Kaze, such as requesting a plushie for their living room.

key_stories.title: On-the-fly Memory Allocator
key_stories.summary: When faced with a memory-related crash in a large level, Kaze quickly diagnosed the problem and programmed a custom per-level memory allocation system during the stream to solve it.
key_stories.challenge: The game was crashing in a large ice level because it was running out of memory allocated for collision surfaces.
key_stories.process: After identifying the issue as too many collision triangles for the default memory pool, Kaze decided to write new code on the spot. He implemented a function that checks the current level ID and dynamically sets a larger memory pool size for the problematic level.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a flexible system that allocates memory for collision data based on the specific needs of each level, solving the crash without wasting memory in smaller levels.
key_stories.key_quote: Yeah, I made my own memory allocator. What about it?

key_stories.title: Refactoring the Mirror System
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified that the game's mirror logic was inefficient and difficult to work with. He refactored the entire system live on stream, resulting in a much more flexible and developer-friendly implementation.
key_stories.challenge: The existing method for creating mirrors in the game was clunky, difficult to use, and had confusing, hardcoded variables.
key_stories.process: Kaze analyzed the flawed old system and designed a new data structure to define a mirror's properties (axis, position, range). He then rewrote the C code to process this new structure and updated all existing mirrors in the game to use the new system, testing each one to ensure it worked.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a new, generic mirror system defined by a simple data structure. This makes adding mirrors of any orientation much simpler and more efficient.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, this is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

key_stories.title: The Phishing Attempt
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed a recent, sophisticated phishing attempt he thwarted. His adherence to personal security rules (never running unknown executables) and his diligence in verifying the scammer's identity prevented him from being compromised.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze received a very convincing and personalized offer to advertise a 'web3 teaching school' on his YouTube channel.
key_stories.process: The advertiser seemed legitimate until they asked Kaze to download a custom app (.exe file) for a meeting. Kaze refused, citing a strict personal security rule. When the scammers provided a fake Zoom link, his suspicions were confirmed. He then contacted the person whose GitHub profile the scammer was impersonating.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze avoided the scam and was able to provide information to the real person whose identity was stolen, who happened to work in anti-scam software, potentially helping them track the perpetrators.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm not downloading and running an exe file ever no matter how legit this looks.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that he and Sauraen discovered the game's performance bottleneck was the RSP, not the RDP, which was a major breakthrough for the project. This led to significant performance improvements in FBDX3.
questions: Can you walk me through the process of how you and Sauraen diagnosed the RSP bottleneck? What tools or methods did you use?
What was the moment you realized it was the RSP? Was it a surprise?
How has this discovery fundamentally changed your approach to optimization and level design for the rest of the project?

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to release initial versions with emulator support, but then 'ditch' it to create a definitive version optimized purely for N64 hardware, potentially using features like tri-strips.
questions: What specific N64 hardware features do you unlock by dropping emulator support?
Can you explain what tri-strips are and what kind of performance or visual gains they provide?
This decision could make the game inaccessible to many players. How do you weigh the goal of perfect hardware optimization against the desire for broader accessibility?

open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly mentioned making sure his work is up to a high standard for Biobak, referencing the 'wrath of Biobak' and not wanting to 'insult' him with unfinished work.
questions: Can you describe your collaborative workflow with Biobak? How does a level go from your blockout stage to his final art pass?
How does Biobak's feedback influence your modeling and design decisions? Can you give an example of a time his input led to a significant change?
(To Biobak) What are your standards for the geometry you receive from Kaze? How do you communicate your artistic vision and feedback to him?

open_questions.context: Kaze candidly mentioned becoming a new father as a motivation to work harder, and also spoke about his personal mental health journey.
questions: How has becoming a father changed your perspective on game development, your work-life balance, and the legacy you want to create with this project?
You're very open with your community. How does managing your personal life and mental health intersect with the immense pressure and focus required for a project of this scale?
(To Zeina) How do you see Kaze's personal life and his creative work influencing each other from your perspective as both his wife and a collaborator?

open_questions.topic: Future Potential of the FBDX3 Microcode
open_questions.context: Kaze is clearly excited about the potential of the FBDX3 microcode but admits he has a lot to learn before he can contribute to it, and is waiting for Sauraen to finish his work.
questions: What are some of the 'cool new triangle drawing algorithms' you hope to create with FBDX3 once you've mastered it?
Describe your collaborative relationship with Sauraen. How does it work when one person is developing such a fundamental part of the engine you rely on?
What is the single biggest creative limitation of the original SM64 engine that you are most excited to overcome with FBDX3?
